# The `MachOPlatform` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

Mediates between <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/macho">MachO</a> initialization and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/executionsession">ExecutionSession</a> state. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Description {#details}

Mediates between <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/macho">MachO</a> initialization and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/executionsession">ExecutionSession</a> state.

Definition at line 30 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/executionengine/include/llvm/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-h">MachOPlatform.h</a>.

### buildSimpleMachOHeaderMU() {#a49136cf1b05dde0d5cea41910deb238e}

  prototype={<>std::unique&#95;ptr&lt; MaterializationUnit &gt; llvm::orc::MachOPlatform::buildSimpleMachOHeaderMU (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/machoplatform">MachOPlatform</a> &amp; MOP, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/orc/machoplatform/headeroptions">HeaderOptions</a> Opts)</>}

Simple <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/macho">MachO</a> header graph builder.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/executionengine/include/llvm/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-h/#l00095">95</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/executionengine/include/llvm/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-h">MachOPlatform.h</a>.

### Create() {#ad166f5736231229286c93cd8c6aa8b6d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Expected&lt; std::unique&#95;ptr&lt; MachOPlatform &gt; &gt; llvm::orc::MachOPlatform::Create (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/objectlinkinglayer">ObjectLinkingLayer</a> &amp; ObjLinkingLayer, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/jitdylib">JITDylib</a> &amp; PlatformJD, std::unique&#95;ptr&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/definitiongenerator">DefinitionGenerator</a> &gt; OrcRuntime, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/orc/machoplatform/headeroptions">HeaderOptions</a> PlatformJDOpts=&#123;&#125;, <a href="#a93b754ab1a755ecf25e98f2bea459d8d">MachOHeaderMUBuilder</a> BuildMachOHeaderMU=<a href="#a49136cf1b05dde0d5cea41910deb238e">buildSimpleMachOHeaderMU</a>, std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/orc/#adfa7bcc2544e48c4531ebfe74ae622b2">SymbolAliasMap</a> &gt; RuntimeAliases=std::nullopt)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Try to create a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/machoplatform">MachOPlatform</a> instance, adding the ORC runtime to the given <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/jitdylib">JITDylib</a>.

The ORC runtime requires access to a number of symbols in libc++, and requires access to symbols in libobjc, and libswiftCore to support Objective-C and Swift code. It is up to the caller to ensure that the required symbols can be referenced by code added to PlatformJD. The standard way to achieve this is to first attach dynamic library search generators for either the given process, or for the specific required libraries, to PlatformJD, then to create the platform instance:


<ProgramListing extension="cpp">

<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">auto</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> &amp;PlatformJD = ES.createBareJITDylib(</span><span class="doxyHighlightStringLiteral">&quot;stdlib&quot;</span><span class="doxyHighlight">);</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">PlatformJD.addGenerator(</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">  ExitOnErr(EPCDynamicLibrarySearchGenerator</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">              ::GetForTargetProcess(EPC)));</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">ES.setPlatform(</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">  ExitOnErr(<a href="#ad166f5736231229286c93cd8c6aa8b6d">MachOPlatform::Create</a>(ES, ObjLayer, EPC, PlatformJD,</span></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><span class="doxyHighlight">                                  </span><span class="doxyHighlightStringLiteral">&quot;/path/to/orc/runtime&quot;</span><span class="doxyHighlight">)));</span></CodeLine>

</ProgramListing>


Alternatively, these symbols could be added to another <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/jitdylib">JITDylib</a> that PlatformJD links against.

Clients are also responsible for ensuring that any JIT&#39;d code that depends on runtime functions (including any code using TLV or static destructors) can reference the runtime symbols. This is usually achieved by linking any JITDylibs containing regular code against PlatformJD.

By default, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/orc/machoplatform">MachOPlatform</a> will add the set of aliases returned by the standardPlatformAliases function. This includes both required aliases (e.g. &#95;&#95;cxa&#95;atexit -&gt; &#95;&#95;orc&#95;rt&#95;macho&#95;cxa&#95;atexit for static destructor support), and optional aliases that provide JIT versions of common functions (e.g. dlopen -&gt; &#95;&#95;orc&#95;rt&#95;macho&#95;jit&#95;dlopen). Clients can override these defaults by passing a non-None value for the RuntimeAliases function, in which case the client is responsible for setting up all aliases (including the required ones).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/executionengine/include/llvm/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-h/#l00136">136</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/executionengine/include/llvm/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-h">MachOPlatform.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-cpp/#l00280">280</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/executionengine/lib/executionengine/orc/machoplatform-cpp">MachOPlatform.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### standardRuntimeUtilityAliases() {#a5033eefe5c3bcf123e9d3070884f38f5}

  prototype={<>ArrayRef&lt; std::pair&lt; const char &#42;, const char &#42; &gt; &gt; llvm::orc::MachOPlatform::standardRuntimeUtilityAliases ()</>}
